description: LeastCostScheduler.weigh_hosts() is supposed to return one host per instance to be booted, but instead only returns a weighted list of the hosts. This means that a request for 10 instances in a zone with 2 compute nodes will only result in 2 instances booted, when all 10 could be booted.
title: LeastCostScheduler.weigh_hosts() doesn't return enough hosts

comments.content: LeastCostScheduler.weigh_hosts() is supposed to return one host per instance to be booted, but instead only returns a weighted list of the hosts. This means that a request for 10 instances in a zone with 2 compute nodes will only result in 2 instances booted, when all 10 could be booted.
comments.author: https://api.launchpad.net/1.0/~klmitch

comments.content: Hm.  Wonder if this should be fixed in AbstractScheduler's schedule_run_instance()... vs what was changed in Rev 1534 for BaseScheduler.   The fix for 1534 doesn't give us much, because most subclasses from Base will override weigh_hosts (like LeastCost does).
comments.author: https://api.launchpad.net/1.0/~cbehrens

comments.content: Sandy was of the opinion that this should be addressed in the various weigh_hosts() functions.  His basic thesis was that weigh_hosts() in classes other than BaseScheduler are responsible for keeping an updated picture of the available resources for a given host.  It wouldn't make sense to get 5 cases of a specific host if that host could only handle having 3 instances.
